Elliotte's question is very valid, I think -- even if *you* don't  
have a problem with your credit card number being more or less public  
(I know I don't), protecting it is a typical user requirement. If you  
try to argue with a customer that what they want to see protected is  
not confidential at all, you've already lost the argument :-)

Still, I believe the "best" answer is that REST (or at least HTTP)  
relies on identifiers that are not secrets. If your identifiers are  
(or you consider them to be) secret, don't use them as URIs.

My personal favorite solution would be to create a new resource  
representing an application-specific "account" via posting the credit  
card number, and return a non-meaningful URI for that newly created  
(and reasonably protected) resource.

Stefan
